page.paragraph: Now listen to two students as they discuss the brochure.
Hi, Alice.
Oh, hi, Don.
Listen, Alice, you're thinking of getting the certificate in technical writing, too, aren't you?
Yes, I am. You mean, you're thinking about getting it, too?
I am, but I'm a little confused about something.
You are? About what?
Well, did you read the brochure about the certificate program?
Yes, I did.
Well, did you see the part about how many units are required?
Yes. The brochure said that 25 units are required. That doesn't sound like too much, does it? We can finish 25 units pretty quickly.
You're right about that, but I just don't see how we can get a certificate with 25 units.
You don't? But the brochure says that 25 units are required for the certificate.
Yes, it does, but then it says that there is an eight-unit introductory course that's required.
Yes, it does.
And it says that the remaining units should be taken in elective courses.
That's right, too.
Well, if 25 units are required and if eight of these units are in an introductory course, then that leaves 17 units, doesn't it?
Yes, it does, but I still don't see what the problem is.
Well, here's the problem. Each of the elective courses is four units each, so if we take four elective courses, then that's 16 units.
OK, now I see what the problem is. If all of the electives are four-unit courses, then there's no way to take just 25 units.
That's right. So we're going to have to take more than 25 units to get this certificate.
